linkTarget.anchoringText: Other applications such as well performance or flow assurance simulators might use black-oil or lumped Equation-of-State (EOS) models. Thus, PVT consistency becomes an issue whenever an IAM model is developed. To overcome this challenge, the IAM platform must be able to handle consistently complex petroleum streams, described with different fluid models (black-oil, lumped EOS or detailed EOS), see Fig. 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Challenges of fluid modeling consistency across a petroleum production system (after Astutik et al. (2017)).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Challenges of fluid modeling consistency across a petroleum production system (after Astutik et al. (2017)).

linkTarget.bib:
Astutik et al., 2017
W. Astutik , A. Hoffmann , F. Rasmussen , and C. Whitson
H., Optimal Management of Topside Diluent Injection for a Heavy Oil Field , SPE-183802-MS, 2017.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures 2 (a) and (b) show the typical workflow of IAM optimization. The optimization process is called “black-box” optimization. The non-linear solver is calling the integrated model (the black-box) multiple times. After each execution of the integrated model, the objective function and the constraints are evaluated and fed back to the solver. At each solver iteration, partial derivatives in respect of each variables may be required and estimated (when not analytically available) using finite differences, see Fig. 2 (c).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: IAM optimization. Black-box optimization workflow., Model-base optimization routine (after Stanko et al. (2015)), Typical convergence for a black-box optimization problem., Convergence towards the global maximum with two different starting points (after Juell et al. (2009)).

formatted-caption.caption-text: IAM optimization. Black-box optimization workflow., Model-base optimization routine (after Stanko et al. (2015)), Typical convergence for a black-box optimization problem., Convergence towards the global maximum with two different starting points (after Juell et al. (2009)).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Model-base optimization routine (after Stanko et al. (2015))
Typical convergence for a black-box optimization problem
Convergence towards the global maximum with two different starting points (after Juell et al. (2009))

linkTarget.anchoringText: It consists of two reservoirs (L for light and H for heavy) with respective API gravities of 14 and 12 API degrees, and oil viscosities at reservoir conditions of 70 cp and 500 cp. The field includes some 60 production wells with Electrical Submersible Pump (ESP) for the artificial lift. The processing facility consists of a 2-stage separation train followed by a coalescer aimed to separate water from oil. Diluent is planned to be injected (1) in each individual well at the ESP and (2) in the surface processing facility prior to the second stage separator, see Fig. 3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Diluent injection system (after Hoffmann et al. (2016)). Diluent injection points., Downhole diluent injection system.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Diluent injection system (after Hoffmann et al. (2016)). Diluent injection points., Downhole diluent injection system.

linkTarget.bib:
Hoffmann et al., 2016
A. Hoffmann , W. Astutik , F. Rasmussen , and C. Whitson
H., Diluent Injection Optimization for a Heavy Oil Field , SPE-184119-MS, 2016.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Hoffmann et al. (2016) and Astutik et al. (2017) propose an integrated optimization solution that integrates (1) the two reservoir simulation models (one for each reservoir), (2) the well performance models, and (3) the surface process model, see Fig. 4. The black-oil rates from the reservoir simulator are fed to the individual well models for downhole diluent injection optimization and to the process simulation for topside diluent injection optimization.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Integrated asset model built within Pipe-It (after Astutik et al. (2017)).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Integrated asset model built within Pipe-It (after Astutik et al. (2017)).

linkTarget.bib:
Astutik et al., 2017
W. Astutik , A. Hoffmann , F. Rasmussen , and C. Whitson
H., Optimal Management of Topside Diluent Injection for a Heavy Oil Field , SPE-183802-MS, 2017.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The integrated model is used to forecast optimal downhole (by well) and topside diluent requirements over time and foresee eventual bottlenecks in the surface infrastructure design. Results are shown in Fig. 5. The solution enables the additional recovery of 3 million std m3 (+ 6 % compared to the base case) while minimizing the need of downhole diluent injection. Topside diluent injection optimization contributes to lower OPEX by minimizing the quantity of diluent required topside.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Results extracted from the integrated model (after Hoffmann et al. (2016) and Astutik et al. (2017)) Incremental reservoir oil production obtained by downhole diluent injection., Quantity of diluent injected., Optimized topside diluent injection., Viscosity at 40°C of the final crude.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Results extracted from the integrated model (after Hoffmann et al. (2016) and Astutik et al. (2017)) Incremental reservoir oil production obtained by downhole diluent injection., Quantity of diluent injected., Optimized topside diluent injection., Viscosity at 40°C of the final crude.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Incremental reservoir oil production obtained by downhole diluent injection
Viscosity at 40°C of the final crude

linkTarget.anchoringText: The detailed and consistent PVT modeling across the production system enables to run very complex sensitivity analyses on the type of diluent, see Fig. 6. These studies can lead to more-informed decisions and ultimately lower OPEX and therefore higher revenues.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Potential savings by injecting a lighter diluent (after Astutik et al. (2017)). Cumulative topside diluent demand., Diluent loss.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Potential savings by injecting a lighter diluent (after Astutik et al. (2017)). Cumulative topside diluent demand., Diluent loss.

Astutik et al., 2017

linkTarget.anchoringText: The studied asset is located in South America and consists of seven fields including gas condensate, near-critical oil and volatile oil reservoirs. Each reservoir fluid is characterized with its own EOS model. A total of 85 production wells are connected to 5 processing facilities, see Fig. 7.

The molar rates coming from different wells are then aggregated together and fed to the process simulation model. Each processing facility is modelled within Pipe-It using a multi-stage separation model and simplified model for units involving energy balance (e.g. distillation tower), see Fig. 8. Process (p, T) conditions are given as user input for each separation vessel.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Processing facility A modelled within Pipe-It.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Processing facility A modelled within Pipe-It.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The well molar rates are then processed individually using the pseudo K-values as a proxy model for the process and volumetric contributions of individual wells can be calculated. The reason for using the pseudo K-values instead a full EOS process simulation when processing individual well lies in the influence of the feed stream composition on the process efficiency. The pseudo K-values capture that effect with a satisfying degree of accuracy. Figure 9 summarizes the proposed workflow.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Proposed compositional production allocation workflow. Input data are shown in a red.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proposed compositional production allocation workflow. Input data are shown in a red.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The difference between simulated and fiscal rates reaches 20 % when using traditional back-allocation methods. When using a full compositional approach, the discrepancy drops to 2 % for oil and 3-4 % for gas, see Fig. 10. This significant improvement lies in the very detailed fluid description and stream management. Molecules are tracked from the well to the sales point and back-allocation is performed on a compositional basis rather than a volumetric basis.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Comparison between model-based rates and fiscal rates for facility C. Oil rate., Gas rate.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison between model-based rates and fiscal rates for facility C. Oil rate., Gas rate.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The South Natuna Sea Block B (SNSBB) PSC, shown in Fig. 11, contains numerous oil and gas fields from various sub-basins in greater West Natuna. In the Western area of SNSBB, also referred to as the “dry gas” area, several fields are already on stream and other fields are in various stages of development. The gas is collected and compressed for export at the Hang Tuah facility. The gas produced from these “dry gas” fields is very lean and requires minimal processing prior to export.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Detailed process simulation requires a consistent aggregate molar rate profile for proper equipment sizing and efficient process design. These detailed streams can be provided using the integrated model, see Fig. 13.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this project, the focus was to maintain a desired API of sales oil for the entire forecast period while conserving the potential from high grade reservoirs. The optimization yielded a production strategy where the target rate of low grade reservoirs with high potential was increased and the target rate of high grade reservoirs with medium potential was reduced. This resulted in a substantial increase in plateau duration for the entire field as shown in Figure 15.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Implementation of blending optimization within Pipe-It.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Implementation of blending optimization within Pipe-It.

linkTarget.anchoringText: With an automated and accurate integrated system covering the entire value chain from the reservoir to the surface, a host of development strategies can be studied. In this project, the focus was to maintain a desired API of sales oil for the entire forecast period while conserving the potential from high grade reservoirs. The optimization yielded a production strategy where the target rate of low grade reservoirs with high potential was increased and the target rate of high grade reservoirs with medium potential was reduced. This resulted in a substantial increase in plateau duration for the entire field as shown in Figure 15.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of the sales oil rate and API gravity before and after blending optimization. API vs time, Sales oil rate vs time

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of the sales oil rate and API gravity before and after blending optimization. API vs time, Sales oil rate vs time
